conversations.content: A Guardian's Promise: Part One
Deep within a vast forest, secluded from the outside world, there lived a single dragon.
She was the forest's guardian, and her name was Sylvia. Kind of heart, she loved both nature and solitude, and drove away any human who sought to enter her home.
As a dragon, she had witnessed humanity's history unfold for centuries, and had seen their foolishness, selfishness, and desire for conflict first-hand.
＂If fighting really is human nature,＂ she often thought, ＂then I will do all I can to keep them from this place, so that it may continue to be one of peace and tranquility.＂
But one day, a group came to the forest who were very different from all those she had seen before.
The gentle woman leading the group lowered her head deeply to Sylvia. ＂Guardian of this forest,＂ she said, ＂pray grant we sylvans leave to live here, for we have heard much of it.＂
Grastaea was then a land of strife, with large nations fighting for control of the continent. Their homes razed, the sylvans had no choice but to seek refuge in the woods.
Sylvia was a kind-hearted dragon, and seeing pitiable sylvans free of malice and ill intent, she could not simply turn them away.
＂Very well,＂ said Sylvia. ＂You may live here. But I have two conditions. You must promise to avoid conflict— no matter how trivial—and you may not bear arms of any kind.＂
Without hesitation, the sylvans threw away their weapons. In truth, they bore them only for self-defense, and knew they were useless against foes of even the slightest strength.
Thus, the sylvans built their settlement deep within the forest and began to live side-by-side with Sylvia.
The sylvans were filled with kindness and love at the dragon's gift, and went on to live in harmony with one another.
They also respected Sylvia and all the forest's creatures—as well as nature as a whole. And seeing their way of life, the dragon was forced to rethink her views.
Clearly, not everyone was worthy of contempt; some loved peace and nature just as she did. Realizing this, Sylvia swore to be the guardian of the sylvans as well as the forest.
Just then, however, tragedy struck, for the flames of war finally reached the forest in which she lived.
A Guardian's Promise: Part Two
A group of sylvans came to Sylvia's forest fleeing war, and she permitted them to settle there provided they lived free of conflict and did not bear arms of any sort.
Seeing their way of life, she had been forced to accept that not all people were despicable, and so swore to serve as their guardian.
However, the war they had fled showed no signs of ending, and finally reached their new home. At this, Sylvia immediately rose up to defend them.
＂You have nothing to fear, sylvans,＂ she assured them. ＂For no matter what may come, I will keep you safe from harm.＂
But Sylvia had underestimated the evil a human heart is capable of. For it was not an army of men that arrived in the forest, but legions of fiends under their command.
The battle between nations had become so fierce that they had begun to fight using fiends—and Sylvia's forest had tragically become the site for their latest battle.
The fiends trampled the forest like a great storm, and much as Sylvia tried, many sylvans lost their lives.
She was filled with regret, for the sylvans had no means to defend themselves. If she had permitted them weapons, however weak, perhaps some might have lived.
＂If I hadn't forced them to give up their arms...＂  ＂If I hadn't taken away their only means of defending themselves...＂
Sylvia went to the sylvans' leader— who had barely survived the battle— and asked them to take up arms in self-defense once more.
＂You may one day be faced again with a disaster I cannot save you from,＂ she said. ＂And if you do not have the means or the will to fight, you will perish.＂
＂I believe in you. I know you will not use those weapons for your own self-interest like savages. Instead, you will use them only to protect that which you hold dear.＂
Thus the sylvans once more took up arms—but only to protect others from conflict, as opposed to causing it.
Within their kindness, they also possessed great strength and courage—and that courage still persists in the sylvans who live in that settlement today.
